body: hi amaia, this issue came up with our other interval classifiers, @MatthewMiddlehurst may remember the context? I think the feature importance stuff is his. I think having this as an option would be good, but perhaps discuss on slack first? I'm not on top of this code myself
@fkiraly @TonyBagnall I agree, let's discuss it on slack

Is this issue available for taking up? I understand why curve normalization could be helpful to remove the unwanted bias. It will be my first time contributing, so some pointers before starting would be much appreciated!

I have something currently ready for this, just not made a PR as it accompanies a bunch of other stuff. 

Feel free to resolve this yourself, I would recommend adding it as an option to normalise or not rather than just replacing what is currently there.

Thanks, @MatthewMiddlehurst @aabanda
To ensure I am going in the right direction, the following are the points that need to be taken care of: 
• Add a bool parameter in the BaseTimeSeriesForest class in 
 sktime/sktime/series_as_features/base/estimators/_ensemble.py
• Initialise the fis_count dataframe and fill it with the number of empirical intervals for each point 
• If the bool parameter's True, return the fis_norm dataframe (as shown in the code snippet attached by @aabanda), else return the fis dataframe. 
Do let me know if I missed something.

issue.title: tsf importance curve normalization

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #669

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
--> Fixes #669




#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
--> An option has been provided for the user if they want to normalize the importance curve by considering the fact that different time indices occur in the different numbers of intervals. Some cases might not require them to do so, as rightly pointed out by @TonyBagnall and @MatthewMiddlehurst and hence it is user-dependent.
I do this by assigning two variables: normalise_option ('False' initially) and normalise_type (I will be building on it later so I have just initialised it for now).
Based on the preference stored in normalise_option, user can either fis_norm or fis in return. fis_norm will be obtained by dividing the fis by fis_count that is obtained by empirical value addition as @aabanda suggests. 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
--> Nope

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->
Just the edits in the code. 

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
--> For future: I think we can add more kinds of normalizations. Apart from just based on count, we can have normalization based on maximum occurrence of intervals or mean occurrence in intervals.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body:
Hello, I added an option for normalizing the importance curve if the user needs that given the objective and dataset that they might be working on based on what @aabanda, @TonyBagnall, and @MatthewMiddlehurst  suggested.
I also think that we could include more types of normalization as options if we are at it. Sometimes when the range of the time series dataset might be very large, the users might need normalization based on the maximal value among all the empirical counts. Additionally, we can also normalize based on the average or median. These choices could be provided in a separate variable 'normalise_type' that will take in the input once users set 'normalise_option' as 'True'. The default value could be empirical count as suggested by @aabanda but we could also add other options.
Please let me know what you think!
